Kerri Walsh Jennings, who has won three consecutive gold medals and is the most decorated beach volleyball player in history, is potentially considering a return for Paris 2024.

Acrobatic gymnastics evolved as a captivating discipline through the artful use of apparatus and dynamic tumbling, both highlighting the extraordinary potential of the human body. The pioneering competition rules for acrobatics originated in the Soviet Union, where massive crowds packed stadiums, eager to witness awe-inspiring athletic displays, including the formation of towering human pyramids. The inaugural Soviet national championships took place in 1939, marking a historic moment in the sport's development.

Originally, basketball was played with peach baskets, and players had to retrieve the ball manually after each score. To address this, a hole was drilled into the bottom of the basket so the ball could be pushed out with a long rod. In 1906, the peach baskets were replaced by metal hoops with backboards.

In breaking competitions, the energy soars as two breakers face off in a high-stakes showdown. One breaker sets the stage with their performance, and their opponent steps up to respond, aiming to outshine. Five judges meticulously score the athletes across six thrilling criteria: creativity, personality, technique, variety, performativity, and musicality. Throughout the competition, each judge uses a tablet to dynamically adjust sliders, determining the scores for each electrifying element.

3x3 basketball brings an exciting twist to the traditional game, transforming it into a fast-paced, urban sensation. Played on a half-court with just three players per team, this innovative format features intense action around a single hoop and backboard. Celebrated as the world's top urban team sport, 3x3 basketball captures the vibrant energy of city life and delivers non-stop thrills.

Cuba and the United States have long dominated Olympic boxing, while Great Britain and Russia are also recognized for their prowess in the sport. In women's Olympic boxing, Britain, Ireland, and the United States have achieved the greatest success to date.

A batter scores runs by hitting the ball and running to the other end of the pitch while their partner runs to their initial position. When an odd number of runs is scored, the batter's partner will face the next ball. If the batter hits the ball to the boundary, they score four runs, and if the ball clears the boundary without touching the ground, they score six runs. A bowler delivers an over, which consists of six consecutive balls, after which another bowler takes over from the opposite end of the pitch for the next over.

England, set to represent Great Britain at the 2028 Los Angeles Games, triumphed over Pakistan in the 2022 T20 World Cup final. Star players include the explosive wicketkeeper Jos Buttler and the stellar spin bowler Adil Rashid.
In Paris 2024, the breaking competition will feature two events—one for men and one for women—where 16 B-Boys and 16 B-Girls will compete in thrilling solo battles.

In 1948, the Union Internationale de Pentathlon Moderne et Biathlon (UIPMB) came into existence to unify and regulate the rules governing biathlon and pentathlon. Fast forward to 1993, and the UIPMB's biathlon division established its own entity, the International Biathlon Union (IBU), ultimately becoming an independent organization in 1998.
Bicycle motocross (BMX) began in late 1960s California, inspired by the rising popularity of motocross in the USA.

The sport quickly grew in popularity. In 1877, the newly formed Bath Badminton Club devised the first set of written rules. Sixteen years later, the Badminton Federation of England was created. In 1899, it organized the first All England Championships.

At the 1924 Chamonix Olympic Winter Games, a four-man bobsleigh race debuted. A two-man event followed in the 1932 Lake Placid Games and remains today. In 2002, the first women's bobsleigh event, the two-woman bobsled, was introduced. Monobob made its Olympic debut at the 2016 Winter Youth Olympic Games in Lillehammer, featuring identical bobs for all competitors, emphasizing driving skill over equipment. The women's monobob is now included in the Beijing 2022 program.

At the dawn of the 21st century, the International Cricket Council's nine "Full Members" included India, Australia, England, New Zealand, Pakistan, Sri Lanka, South Africa, Zimbabwe, and the West Indies, a unique team combining talents from regions such as Jamaica, Barbados, and Trinidad and Tobago.

Special curling shoes are designed for good ice grip. During shooting, very slippery materials like Teflon are used on the sliding foot; these can be either built into the shoes or strapped over them.
Two teams of nine players compete to score the most runs by hitting a ball and running around a series of bases to reach home plate.

BMX racing has traditionally been dominated by European and U.S. athletes, with notable riders like Niek Kimmann, Sylvain André, Bethany Shriever, and Laura Smulders leading the sport. Colombian riders, especially three-time Olympic medallist Mariana Pajón, have also achieved top-level success.
In cricket regulations, the sole variation between men's and women's games is that women use a slightly smaller and lighter ball.

Artistic swimming encompasses several disciplines, with women participating in the majority. Olympic events include women's duets and teams, which combine free and technical routines. Additionally, there are solo routines for both men and women, mixed duets, mixed teams, and women's acrobatic events.

Male athletes born on or before December 31, 2006 (17 years old at Paris 2024) are eligible to compete in the men's event. Female athletes born on or before December 31, 2008 (15 years old at Paris 2024) are eligible to compete in the women's competition.

Despite its initial niche status, FIBA recognized the unique appeal of 3x3 basketball and subsequently formalized it as a distinct discipline. This initiative aimed to diversify the sport's reach and create additional avenues for engagement amongst its member associations and players globally. By establishing professional standards and official regulations, FIBA sought to elevate 3x3 basketball into a reputable and organized facet of the sport.

Picture this: the shimmering pools of Helsinki in 1952 where the world first witnessed the grace of synchronised swimming as a dazzling demonstration sport. Fast forward to Los Angeles 1984, and the sport finally dove into the spotlight, capturing hearts and awarding medals in women's duet and women's solo for the first time in Olympic history.

Matches are decided based on a best-of-three format, wherein the first two sets are played to 21 points and the third set, if necessary, is played to 15 points. A team must achieve a two-point advantage to secure a set. In the event of a tie at 21-21, play continues until one team attains a two-point lead, such as 23-21.

In men's professional boxing, championship matches comprise twelve three-minute rounds and are adjudicated by three ringside judges. In non-championship matches of shorter durations, the referee assumes the additional role of scorer.

Athletics is a sport encompassing various events that involve running, jumping, throwing, or walking. Commonly known as track and field, it features individual events like the 100m sprint, marathon, and long jump; combined events such as the decathlon and heptathlon; and team events like the 4x100m relays.
Some of the best guys to ever play men's basketball have hit the Olympic stage, like NBA legends Michael Jordan, Magic Johnson, LeBron James, and Larry Bird, just to name a few.

For the men's competition, Japan's Hashimoto Daiki is expected to be a top contender, having secured two gold medals at Tokyo 2020 in the all-around and horizontal bars events. At just 20 years old, he also earned a silver medal in the team event, demonstrating his ability to lead the Japanese team following the retirement of legendary seven-time Olympic medallist Uchimura Kohei.

Plato, Aristotle, and Homer enthusiastically championed the invigorating benefits of gymnastic exercises. Over two millennia ago, the Ancient Greeks were convinced that true harmony between the mind and body could only be achieved by combining physical workouts with intellectual pursuits.

The women's team event was introduced at the 1996 Atlanta Olympics, replacing the other two synchronized swimming disciplines. However, starting with the 2000 Sydney Olympics, both team and duet competitions have been held.
Cuba snagged the gold medal when the sport first hit the big stage and ended up winning it three times in total before it got cut from the Olympics after Beijing 2008.

In an international basketball match, the game consists of 10-minute quarters, resulting in a total duration of 40 minutes. In contrast, the NBA features 12-minute quarters. Timeouts also vary; during international games, each timeout is one minute long. Teams receive two timeouts in the first half, three in the second half, and one during overtime.

A 3x3 basketball game lasts a maximum of 10 minutes. The first team to score 21 points immediately wins. If neither team reaches 21 points within 10 minutes, the team with the higher score at the end of the game is declared the winner.

Artistic gymnastics made its debut at the inaugural Olympic Games in Athens in 1896 and has been a staple of every Games since. Initially, it included events that were challenging to categorize as artistic, such as climbing and acrobatics.

Olympic beach volleyball is a team sport where two players on each side compete on a sand court separated by a net. The goal is to hit the ball using only hands or arms over the net into the opponent's side until they cannot return it or the ball goes out of bounds. Each rally awards one point.

Each arrow can earn between 0 to 10 points, with the maximum awarded for hitting the target's smallest rings. If an arrow touches the line dividing two scoring zones, the higher score is given. Additionally, there is usually an innermost ring that also grants 10 points and serves as a tie-breaker when necessary. After every set of three arrows per competitor, the archer with the higher score wins the set and receives 2 set points in the match.

The first races used wooden skeleton sleds. These were soon replaced by steel sleds, called bobsleighs because the teams bobbed back and forth to go faster at the start. Today, top teams train all year and race on artificial ice tracks using advanced sleds made of fiberglass and steel.

India, a nation fervently passionate about cricket and spearheaded by the formidable batters Rohit Sharma and Virat Kohli, stands as a dominant force in the sport. Alongside India, Australia also holds a significant position in international cricket. In 2021, New Zealand reached a historic milestone by capturing their first major tournament victory, securing the title of World Test champions.

The earliest documented beach volleyball match took place at Hawaii's Waikiki Beach in 1915, specifically at the Outrigger Canoe Club. On a day with no waves, coach and club leader George Center erected a net on the shoreline and introduced a volleyball to amuse the club's members.

As the name suggests, this thrill unfolds right on the streets. Riders transform urban obstacles into their playground, executing jaw-dropping tricks on anything they find. The essence of street riding is all about the adventure—seeking out new spots and uncharted terrain just waiting to be conquered.

Experience the exhilarating energy of 3x3 basketball at its peak, set against the backdrop of the iconic Place de la Concorde in the heart of Paris. This renowned venue will host the urban sports featured in the Olympic program, offering a truly electrifying atmosphere you won't want to miss.

Played on a half-court, two teams of three players take turns attacking and defending the same hoop, depending on who has the ball. You can win in two ways: having the most points after 10 minutes, or hitting 21 points first.

In the thrilling world of Vert, short for vertical, riders showcase their skills on a towering U-shaped ramp that pushes the limits of gravity. With sheer vertical walls at the top, elite athletes catapult themselves up to an astonishing 4.5 meters above the ramp, defying physics with every breathtaking trick.

Skiing boasts a rich and ancient history. The inception of contemporary downhill skiing is frequently traced back to the 1850s. During this time, Norwegian icon Sondre Norheim revolutionized the sport by introducing skis with curved edges, durable heel band bindings crafted from willow, and pioneering techniques such as the Telemark and Christiania (slalom) turns.
The pitcher throws the ball from a mound toward the catcher, while the batter tries to hit it and run around the bases to score at home plate.
Boxing is a type of unarmed combat in which athletes try to punch their opponent's head or upper body to score points, as determined by judges, or to incapacitate the opponent.
All archers will compete in a ranking round of 72 arrows, with a maximum possible score of 720. The top 64 archers in each individual event will qualify for a seeded single-elimination bracket.

The term "artistic gymnastics" was coined in the early 1800s to highlight the graceful, fluid styles that set it apart from the rigid techniques used in military drills. As gymnastic competitions gained popularity in schools and athletic clubs throughout Europe, they made a triumphant debut at the inaugural modern Olympic Games in Athens in 1896.

Japan's B-Boy Shigekix is consistently a favorite in every men's tournament, alongside 2022 World Champion B-Boy Phil Wizard from Canada. Other prominent figures in the breaking scene include France's B-Boy Danny and Kazakhstan's B-Boy Amir.
Cuban athletes once had to defect to compete professionally, yet boxers like heavyweights Teofilo Stevenson and Felix Savon stayed and achieved greatness in amateur boxing.

In the 1970s, mountain biking emerged as a niche sport in California. While taking a bike off-road was not a novel idea, the advent of a new type of bike designed specifically for rugged terrain was revolutionary. These bikes featured wider tires, rapid-shift gears, drum brakes, and innovative suspension systems. They provided thrill-seeking cyclists with significantly greater freedom, leading to the birth of mountain biking as a recognized sport.

At the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, 18 BMX Freestyle cyclists competed in the Park discipline. In Paris 2024, the number of BMX Freestyle participants will increase by six, making it 24 athletes (12 men and 12 women).

The Republic of Korea is renowned for producing some of the world's finest archers and has maintained a position of dominance in the sport since hosting the 1988 Seoul Games. To date, the country has garnered 43 Olympic medals, including 27 golds, up through the Tokyo 2020 Olympics. Athletes from the Republic of Korea currently hold all five active Olympic records in archery. An San, a standout performer at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, secured three gold medals and holds records in the women's individual ranking round, women's team ranking round, and mixed team ranking round.

The curling sheet ranges in length from 44.501 meters (146 feet) to 45.72 meters (150 feet) and spans a width between 4.42 meters (14 feet 6 inches) and 4.75 meters (15 feet 7 inches), featuring a target or house at each end.

The men's event was inaugurated at the inaugural Winter Olympic Games in Chamonix in 1924, while the women's event made its debut at the 1952 Oslo Games. Historically, the sport has been dominated by the Nordic countries.

To make sure everyone stays safe and the playing field is fair, the sport has some key rules around safety gear, bike sizes, age groups, and how athletes progress through competitions. Events are often organized into 'motos' or heats, where up to 8 racers face off at a time. Depending on the format, these heats can be single-elimination, with only the fastest riders moving forward, or part of a series where racers earn points based on their finishing positions.

Debuting in 1894, artistic gymnastics has been a cornerstone of the modern Olympic Games from the start. Athletes in this discipline strive to master various apparatuses, including the beam and the floor, showcasing their talents and precision.

Back in the 18th century, Norwegian army units were hitting the slopes not just for practice, but for sport and prizes! Fast forward to the mid-19th century, and skiing for fun had truly taken off in Norway, with the first recorded race happening in 1842. By 1892, the excitement had reached new heights with the inauguration of the legendary Holmenkollen ski festival, originally spotlighting the Nordic combined event. But the thrills didn't stop there—in 1901, the festival introduced a separate cross-country race, adding even more adrenaline to the mix.

In the men's and women's team events, the combined scores of the three archers representing each team will be used to determine the team's ranking. The top 12 teams will then advance to compete in a seeded single-elimination bracket.

Four-time Olympic champion Simone Biles faced well-documented mental health challenges at the Tokyo 2020 Games, preventing a repeat of her Rio 2016 triumphs. Despite these hurdles, she still secured a silver and bronze medal. In a recent Facebook Watch discussion, her French coach Cecile Canqueteau-Landi revealed that Biles is contemplating a return for Paris 2024. The prospect of seeing this iconic athlete compete once more is nothing short of exhilarating, as her perseverance and commitment to the sport continue to inspire millions worldwide.
Baseball and softball returned as combined sports with men's baseball and women's softball at the Tokyo 2020 Olympics, where Japan won both gold medals.

Melanie de Jesus dos Santos, a promising athlete from France, will be one to watch. In April 2019, the European all-around champion traveled to the USA to train with Cecile and Laurent Landi, alongside Simone Biles, in preparation for Paris 2024.
The combined scores of each NOC's leading male and female archers will determine their mixed team ranking, with the top 16 NOCs advancing to an exciting single-elimination bracket.
In total, 192 artistic gymnasts will participate in the Paris 2024 Olympics: 96 men and 96 women. This is four fewer than the total number at Tokyo 2020 in 2021.

Basketball is a collaborative game conducted on a rectangular playing area, where two adversary groups, each consisting of five members, aim to score by tossing a ball through the rival team’s hoop and net, commonly referred to as a basket.

In every initial heat on the track, a specific number of competitors will advance to the second round by securing positions that automatically qualify them. Meanwhile, athletes who don't make it into these qualifying spots will get another opportunity to move forward to the semi-finals through the repechage heats.

In 2007, FIBA proposed adding 3x3 basketball to the 2010 Youth Olympic Games in Singapore, where it debuted officially. The discipline has been part of the YOG ever since. On 9 June 2017, the IOC decided to include 3x3 in the Olympic basketball program, starting with the Tokyo 2020 Games, held in 2021. On 24 July 2021, 3x3 became the first new YOG discipline to join the Olympic program. Latvia won the men's gold medal, and the United States secured the women's title.

To win the game, a team needs to score more field goals than the other team by shooting the ball through the opponent's basket. Each team has 24 seconds to make a shot during their possession. If they don't shoot in time, they must give up the ball and switch to defense.

In the preliminary round for both women's and men's tournaments, there are six groups with four teams each. The top two teams from each group will move on to the next round automatically. Teams that did not qualify this way still have a chance to advance through a lucky loser play-off.

By the 1950s, the crucial importance of the start was acknowledged, attracting athletes with explosive strength from other sports to bobsledding. In 1952, a pivotal rule change that set a limit on the total weight of the crew and sled ended the era of super-heavyweight bobsledders and redefined the sport as an athletic competition.

After breaking wowed the crowds at Buenos Aires 2018, the Paris 2024 organizing committee couldn't resist bringing the electrifying dance sport to the French capital for its full Olympic debut. In a thrilling announcement in 2020, the IOC gave the green light, securing breaking's spot on the Paris 2024 programme!

Bobsleigh as a sport started in the late 19th century when the Swiss combined two skeleton sleds, added a steering mechanism, and created a toboggan. They then added a chassis to protect wealthy tourists, and in 1897, the world's first bobsleigh club was established in St. Moritz, Switzerland.

If a team loses all 10 wickets and just one batter is left standing, they're considered 'all out,' signaling the end of their innings. In thrilling T20 cricket, an innings typically concludes after 20 overs. Then, the team batting second faces the exciting challenge of surpassing that score within the same 20 overs without losing all their wickets.

Archery offers a thrilling variety of disciplines, each with its own unique rules and bow types. At the Olympic level, outdoor target archery takes center stage, where athletes use recurve bows to shoot at targets 70 meters away. In a dynamic head-to-head format, competitors battle for set points—2 for a win and 1 for a tie—and the first to reach 6 points claims victory. Beyond the Olympic arena, archery enthusiasts can explore field archery, indoor archery, and para archery, often experimenting with compound bows or the more traditional barebow. Whether you're hitting targets in the great outdoors or under the stadium lights, archery promises an exciting challenge for all.

The ancient Olympic Games dazzled spectators with a range of athletic events that still captivate audiences today: think running, long jump, shot put, and javelin. Fast forward to the inaugural modern Olympics in Athens in 1896, and athletics emerged as a marquee attraction, featuring exhilarating track events from the 100m dash to the 1,500m run, alongside the iconic marathon and thrilling field events like the long jump and pole vault. Flash forward to Tokyo 2020, where athletes showcased their prowess in 26 events—the same electrifying lineup slated for Paris 2024.

At Paris 2024, a total of 48 racers, with 24 in each event, will compete. The competition begins with four quarter-finals, each featuring six racers. The top racers will then move on to two semi-finals, each comprising eight racers, followed by a final also featuring eight racers. The quarter- and semi-final rounds will consist of a series of three heats, whereas the final will be decided by a single race.

From 1980 until 1987, BMX Freestyle saw a significant rise in popularity. In 1982, the discipline established its founding governing body known as the Amateur Skate Park Association (ASPA). A few years later, this organization was renamed the American Freestyle Association (AFA). Eventually, the governance of BMX Freestyle was taken over by the Union Cycliste Internationale (UCI), which remains the global authority for the sport.

The sport blossomed under the vision of Katherine Curtis, who ingeniously merged water acrobatics with music. Her protégés dazzled audiences at the 1933-34 Chicago 'Century of Progress' Fair, where legendary Olympic swimming gold medallist Norman Ross, serving as the announcer, christened the spectacle with the name "synchronized swimming".
ODIs have been shortened to 50 overs per side to fit better with TV schedules and timing needs. In 2003, the England and Wales Cricket Board came up with Twenty20 cricket (or T20).

Boxing first burst onto the Olympic scene in the thrilling St. Louis Games of 1904 and has been a powerhouse presence at every Olympics since—save for a dramatic absence in 1912, when the sport's ban in Sweden kept it out of the Stockholm spotlight.

The United States and Canada initially led the world in Olympic synchronized swimming, but since 2000, Russia (and the ROC at Tokyo 2020) has ruled the sport with an iron grip, clinching every gold medal available in both duet and team events.

The two boxers go head-to-head for several rounds, each usually three minutes long. A referee keeps things in check and can stop the fight if they think one boxer can't go on. The ref can also pause the match for things like dealing with cuts or fixing gear.

Softball originated as an indoor variant of baseball in the year 1887 in Chicago, Illinois. This novel concept was conceived by journalist George Hancock, who was inspired after witnessing an individual strike a boxing glove with a broom handle. Hancock subsequently codified the rules for this nascent sport and extended its play to smaller outdoor fields unsuitable for traditional baseball. Despite the initial ambiguity in regulations, the game garnered increasing interest, culminating in the formation of over 100 high school teams in the surrounding area by 1892.

Although the roots of boxing trace all the way back to Ancient Egypt around 3000 BC, it wasn't until the 16th century that the adrenaline-pumping sport of 'prizefighting' or bare-knuckle boxing truly emerged, captivating audiences primarily in Great Britain.
Top Rock is the foundational dance in breaking, where the breaker stays on foot before transitioning to the floor.

Cricket made its only Olympic appearance way back at the Paris 1900 Games. It featured just one match that lasted two days, with each side getting two innings. In that match, Great Britain's Devon and Somerset Wanderers came out on top against France's French Athletic Club Union.

On the women's side, keep an eye out for Japanese standout B-Girl Ami, the 2022 World Champion, alongside her illustrious teammate, 39-year-old B-Girl Ayumi. Other notable competitors include European Champion B-Girl India from the Netherlands, China's B-Girl 671, and Belgium's B-Girl MadMax, all of whom are making waves in the breaking community.
In April 2022, after a 60-year ban, Cubans, including Tokyo 2020 gold medallists Arlen Lopez and Julio Cesar La Cruz, were allowed to turn professional.

Viktor Axelsen from Denmark and Chen Yufei from China soared to victory as the singles champions at the Tokyo 2020 Olympic Games and still remain top-tier badminton players to watch. Nations like Indonesia, Malaysia, Japan, South Korea, India, Spain, Chinese Taipei, and Singapore have also consistently produced thrilling badminton talent worth following closely.

The Olympic gymnastics programme originated at the 1924 Paris Games with the introduction of men's individual and team apparatus competitions. Women first participated in gymnastics at the 1928 Amsterdam Games. The women's programme expanded to include seven events by the 1952 Games, and later settled at six events starting from the 1960 Games in Rome.

Get ready for an electrifying showdown! This year, the team events are leveling up with 12 squads of five athletes each in the men's and women's categories. A powerful upgrade from the four-member teams at Tokyo 2020, these expanded rosters promise even more thrilling action and competitive drama!

The point value of field goals varies based on the location of the shot. Shots made from within the three-point arc on the court are worth two points, while those taken from beyond the arc are worth three points.
Absolutely! Back in July 2017, swimming's international federation FINA, which is now known as World Aquatics, opted to rename the sport from synchronised swimming to artistic swimming.

Defenders must regain possession by blocking or stealing the ball, but they cannot interfere with a shot on its downward trajectory into the basket. Additionally, both defenders and offensive players are prohibited from staying in the paint, the area directly in front of the basket, for more than three seconds. After reaching this limit, they must exit the space before re-entering.

A batter can be out in a few main ways: bowled (if the ball knocks the bails off the stumps), caught, leg before wicket or LBW (if the ball hits their pads in front of the stumps), and run out (if a fielder uses the ball to knock the bails off before the batter finishes a run).
Limited overs cricket, where teams have a fixed number of overs to score, started in India in 1951. The first one-day international (ODI) was played in 1971.

In 1200 BC, the Hittites and Assyrians became fearsome opponents by shooting bows from chariots. They crafted their bows from tendon, horn, and wood, and developed a re-curved shape, making the bows shorter, more powerful, and easier to handle on horseback.

In Olympic beach handball, four players from a squad of 9 or 10 compete: three outfield players and one goalkeeper. Similar to indoor handball, goals are scored by throwing the ball into the opponent's net. Spectacular goals, such as in-flight shots, spin shots, goalkeeper goals, and penalty throws, earn extra points. The matches are fast-paced, consisting of two 10-minute periods.

Judges evaluate each round independently, awarding 10 points to the boxer they believe exhibited superior performance in terms of punch power and precision, with aggression often being acknowledged positively as well. The boxer who loses the round typically receives nine points, but this can drop to eight if the winner demonstrated significant dominance or managed a knockdown. If the match lasts all scheduled rounds, the final scores on the scorecards will determine the victor.

From the streets of New York to the world’s biggest sports stage: breaking, or breakdancing, is an urban dance style that began in the Bronx in the 1970s. This dance sport combines urban dance with extraordinary athletic skills. Rooted in hip hop culture, it is known for its acrobatic moves.

From its beginnings on urban streets, breaking has evolved and garnered worldwide recognition as an art form, blending music, dance, and athleticism. In the context of the Olympic movement, breaking is a discipline governed by the World DanceSport Federation (WDSF), established in 1957. The inaugural WDSF World DanceSport Games took place in Chinese Taipei in 2013.

The United States has long been a powerhouse in international basketball, consistently showcasing its dominance. This was evident at the Games, where the U.S. clinched every men's title until 1972, when they faced an unexpected defeat by the Soviet Union at the Munich Games.
The 3x3 basketball events at Paris 2024 will occur from 30 July to 5 August, featuring eight men's teams and eight women's teams competing for Olympic medals.
"Biathlon" originates from the Greek word for two contests and combines skiing and shooting. It traces back to survival skills in Scandinavia, where people hunted on skis with rifles.

In the late 1980s, visionary Italian coach Simonetta Montagni pioneered the concept of beach handball. As this thrilling sport gained traction, coach Luciano Bartolini was tasked in 1990 with drafting the inaugural set of rules, ingeniously adapting the high-energy game to the standard beach volleyball court dimensions.

The earliest recorded instance of "baseball" being played dates back to 1749 in Surrey, England. The sport reached the United States by the 1770s, and the first organized professional league, the National Association of Professional Base Ball Players, was established in 1875. Baseball is often referred to as "America's pastime."

Cross-country skiing, the oldest form of skiing, originated from the practical necessity of traversing snow-covered landscapes. Its development into a popular sport occurred in the late 19th century, evolving from a means of transportation to a competitive and recreational activity.

Bobsleigh, a winter sport invented by the Swiss in the late 1860s, involves teams racing down narrow, twisting, banked, and iced tracks in a gravity-powered sled.

Acrobatic gymnastics has a rich and diverse history, spanning thousands of years and numerous cultures. Evidence of acrobatics has been found in Bronze Age artwork, referenced in Homer's epic poems, and featured in Ancient Greek symposiums and the harvest festivals of China's Han Dynasty. Additionally, it provided entertainment for European courts during the Middle Ages.
BMX racing debuted at the Olympics in 2008 in Beijing. Latvia's Maris Strombergs won the men's event, while France's Anne-Caroline Chausson claimed the first women's title.

If a boxer is knocked to the floor by a punch, it is called a knockdown, and the referee starts a count to ten. If the boxer does not get up before the count ends, they are considered knocked out. Additionally, if the referee believes a boxer needs a break after taking a hard punch, they can issue a standing eight count.

In the women's competition, the Soviets secured gold medals in 1976, 1980, and 1992. Following this period, the Americans dominated, claiming every championship from 1984 through to 2020, with the exception of 1992.

Badminton rules have evolved, but the goal is to land the shuttle in the opponent's court without a return. Matches are best of three games to 21 points, with a two-point margin needed to win, except at 29-all, where a single sudden-death point decides the game.

Softball made its debut as a women's medal sport at the 1996 Atlanta Olympic Games, with the United States clinching the first gold medal. The U.S. team went on to win the next two championships and achieved a 22-game winning streak starting in September 2000, until Japan defeated them in the 2008 final.

While most of the competition rules for athletics at Paris 2024 remain the same as in previous Olympic Games, a notable new addition is the introduction of repechage rounds for all individual track events from 200m to 1500m, including hurdles.

Each team consists of 11 players, with one team batting and the other fielding. The fielding team includes at least five bowlers, who deliver the ball with a straight arm (unlike the bent arm of a baseball pitcher) to one of a pair of batters standing on a pitch that is 22 yards (20 meters) long. The batter is tasked with protecting a set of three wooden stumps, topped with two bails, embedded in the ground. Positioned behind these stumps is the wicketkeeper from the fielding team.
In tournaments, they sprinkle water droplets on the artificial ice, creating tiny bumps known as "pebbled ice." This texture helps the stones grip better and results in more consistent curling.

Between 1896 and 1924, gymnastics underwent a transformation into the thrilling sport we celebrate today. Imagine a time when athletes showcased their skills through club swinging, rock lifting, and even swimming, which made a splash in 1922. However, as the sport evolved, these curious disciplines were left behind, giving rise to the modern gymnastics we know and love.

Biathlon-style competitions in Scandinavia date back to the 18th century. The first instance of a modern biathlon likely took place in 1912, when the Norwegian military organized the Forvarsrennet in Oslo. This yearly event originally featured a 17 km cross-country ski race, with missed shots in the shooting segment resulting in two-minute penalties.
In BMX Park competitions, athletes perform tricks on various obstacles like spines, walls, and box jumps. This is the Olympic discipline of BMX Freestyle.
